intro: Dicerandra frutescens var. immaculata, commonly known as the whiteflower dicerandra, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate inflorescences. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, often in rocky soils and open woodlands. Its flowers are small, white, and clustered, with a distinctive scent that attracts pollinators such as flies and beetles. It is considered a rare and endemic species, often found in specific microhabitats within its native range.
